item.title: How It Works
item.description: By typing www will start a web server on port 8000 by default and use as document root the directory where the command was call $ www A different document root may be specified by using the -r option, for example: $ www -r /tmp By default www listen on port 8000, this can be changed by using the -p option: $ www -p 80 may need root privileges

item.title: Let's Encrypt - Free SSL/TLS Certificates
item.description: Just type: www -s your-domain.tld If want to serve content from an specific directory: www -s your-domain.tld -r /tmp That’s it :-). Requirements You need a valid domain/subdomain pointing to a valid public IP, also port 443 needs to be open. Your DNS record may look like this: your-domain.tld IN A X.X.X.X In where X.X.X.X is your public IP

item.title: Errors
item.description: When using option -s yourdomain.tld if you get errors similar like: acme/autocert: certificate is not valid yet acme/autocert: missing server name Besides checking that your domain is pointing to a proper valid IP, also check that your computers clock is synchronised to the network, for this you could use NTP

item.title: About
item.description: What it is www? A web server that serves only static content, it can send traffic in plain HTTP, or HTTPS by using a self signed certificate localhost or using a valid certificate by using letsencrypt. Why ? Because of the need to share, test via HTTP/HTTPS the contents of a directory. The idea came from the need to simplify this commands: python -m SimpleHTTPServer or twistd -n web --path /foo/bar/baz

item.title: pkg install go-www
item.description: To install www on FreeBSD: $ pkg install go-www https://www.freshports.org/www/go-www

item.title: homebrew
item.description: To install www on Mac OS X: $ brew tap nbari/homebrew-www Next: $ brew install www
